title: Schöpfl
text:
Schöpfl is the highest <a href="hill">hill</a> (893 m) in the <a href="Vienna%20Woods">Wienerwald</a> <a href="mountain%20range">mountain range</a> (Vienna woods), the north-easternmost part of the <a href="Alps">Alps</a>. Geologically, it belongs to the <a href="flysch">flysch</a> Alps.
The main top of the wooded mountain range carries a high <a href="observation%20tower">observation tower</a> which enables a 100 km sight to the <a href="Northern%20Limestone%20Alps">Northern Limestone Alps</a> in the west and the <a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the east.
At the "Mitterschöpfl" (approx. 882 m above sea level), the <a href="University%20of%20Vienna">University of Vienna's</a> Leopold Figl observatory is located. Its largest instrument is a <a href="telescope">telescope</a> with a <a href="primary%20mirror">primary mirror</a> of 1.5 m which was constructed in the 1960s. A second tower was built recently for some smaller <a href="astrophysics">astrophysical</a> telescopes.
